instagram post:
â€œLet me ask you something,â€ one hand resting on the trekking pole that rested on his hip. â€œWhy do you backpack? I mean, whoâ€”â€ he trailed off.
â€”
When I first hiked a section of NuÌˆuÌˆmuÌˆ Poyo (the â€œpeopleâ€™s trailâ€ in the Paiute language, also called the John Muir Trail) in 2014, I had just read Wild by Cheryl Strayed. A few years before, Iâ€™d read A Walk in the Woods by Bill Bryson. Iâ€™d read John Krakauerâ€™s Into the Wild. Iâ€™d read Alfred Lansingâ€™s Endurance. As a kid, Iâ€™d read and re-read My Side of the Mountain by Jean Craighead George. In 2014, these were my teachers: the people who ushered me into an idea of nature that I found both compelling and exclusive. I loved these books, and they confused me. I knew in my body that land and race and politics and nature are all lyrics to the same song, but it felt like every time these writers talked about going outside, they didnâ€™t say boo about how white their version of outside was.
â€”
And I return the question to anyone who spends time outside: Who taught you how to be outside? Who teaches you? If your answer is a list of white men or women, know that your understanding of nature is incomplete and impoverished. Read Black, Indigenous, and Asian writers. Support organizations like @indigenouswomenhike , @outdoorafro, @wilddiversity, or @queernature that are working to shift narratives about the outdoors. Go outside, not as an escape from the world and its people, but as a way to connect with all of life more deeply.  Click the link in our bio to read Endria's compelling piece about going to nature to be in the world, not escape it.Â Â  ğŸ“· by: @endriaraa + @narinda___ |#ospreypacks #nature #natureheals

instagram post:
A remembrance is the type of post you never want to write. As outdoor enthusiasts, we often push our limits for the love of nature and occasionally, accidents happen.
â€”
On Sunday August 16th, Osprey ambassador David Xiao was climbing with a partner on Mount Sir Donald near Revelstoke when he fell to his death.  Tuesday would have been his 26th birthday.
â€”
David had an infectious smile and shared his love of the outdoors with everyone he met. From climbing to skiing to thru-hiking, adventure was in his bones. He had a kind and curious soul; the type that radiates positivity and inspires you to try new things. From the lens of his camera, he passionately shared his adventures with us all, so that we too would fall in love with what he loved most.
â€”
â€œI was born and raised within a city of concrete and steel in China and never felt a connection to the outdoors as a kid. I remember the first time my friends took me on a hike after moving to Canada 12 years ago. To my surprise, a hike in the Canadian Rockies meant going out and climbing a mountain, not a walk in the park. I can still picture myself sitting on top of a ridge, mesmerized by the surrounding beauty, the freedom, the joy. I was introduced to a whole new world, a side of reality I never knew existed.â€
â€”
As an Osprey ambassador, we had the joy of helping David pursue his passion for outdoor adventure. When he would talk about the PCT, he lit up. He jumped at every opportunity to share his expertise and knowledge if it would help somebody else try it for the first time.
â€”
When asked if he could make a 20 second phone call to himself at any point in your life, when would you call and what would you say,â€ his response was: To my 14-year-old self: Hey, you know that activity where people strap planks to their feet and slide down mountains really really fast? Sounds silly now but turns out you love it. Go try it now, trust me.
â€”
Thank you David, for sharing your love of the outdoors with so many and being part of the Osprey family. You have taught us to accept any challenge put in our path and to love big. We miss you so much. Rest in peace â€“ may there be many mountains in Heaven for you to climb.
prompt: Create a heartfelt tribute to Osprey ambassador David Xiao, who passed away in a climbing accident, highlighting his love for adventure and the outdoors.

instagram post:
For the past couple weeks, we paused our posts to listen and support the black community and the many black voices that need to be heard. During this time, a global movement took place, inspiring a critical, long-overdue conversation and the beginning of much-needed systems change.
â€”
As an immediate small step, we donated to two organizations that work tirelessly to address the root causes of social injustice and systemic racism in America: NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc. (@naacp) and Color of Change (@colorofchange).
â€”
Moving forward, and with a heightened sense of purpose, we will continue the longstanding relationships we have with Black, Indigenous and People of Colorâ€¯(BIPOC)-focused organizations, like @outdoorafro, @navajo_yes, @latinooutdoors, and more; partner with content creators of color to highlight their work; use our platform to promote BIPOC voices in our blog and social channels; and hold internal meetings to evaluate and identify areas within our business that can be improved.
â€”
Within Osprey, we have been listening to the conversation, asking tough questions, educating ourselves and developing an action plan to make all communities feel safe, welcome and heard. Our DEI committee has a three-year roadmap in place that includes employee and manager training, department reviews, updated hiring practices, policy and procedure analysis, vision creation and employee culture surveys.
â€”
It has been a longstanding goal at Osprey to promote a more diverse community in the outdoorsâ€”and we are committed to the internal, long-term work required to further transform outdoor spaces into a more inclusive environment.
prompt: Write a heartfelt post announcing Osprey's commitment to supporting the Black community and promoting diversity and inclusion in the outdoors.

instagram post:
At our core, we are steadfast in our resolve to leave our world better than we found it. Because of that, weâ€™re choosing not to stay silent on the events of this past week and our nationâ€™s long history of systemic racism. We believe there is simply no place for hatred in our communities, in our outdoor spacesâ€”anywhere in the world, period. We stand with the black community to condemn senseless deaths and injustices that permeate all facets of our society.
â€”
We realize sharing our beliefs is a small step, and weâ€™re pushing ourselves to do better. Better starts with listening more and developing an evolving action plan.
â€”
Starting today, we plan to use our platform for good and to ensure BIPOC voices are heardâ€”that means giving them a platform to speak about experiences, better representing people of color through all of our stories and diversifying the non-profits we partner with to better support our core values.
â€”
Our community is open and inclusive to all. Our differences fuel our strengths. Together we can end inequalityâ€”and we have no patience for those who say thatâ€™s impossible.
â€”
Black Lives Matter. â€”
#blackouttuesday #blackoutday2020

instagram post:
"A little while back, I was able to take my daughter on this trip down the Caprock Canyons State Park Trailway. Easing this kid into more self-sufficiency has been a great experience, and she has really started to come into her own this year. We rode 13 gradually descending miles to the campsite on the western side of the Clarity Tunnel. We had a headwind, the temperature was never above 38 F, and mist and drops of rain were an occasional element. Although we stopped to grab a snack and explore a bit of the trailwayâ€™s history, we didnâ€™t dottle, and Eva kept the pace moving. Like most kids, one of the more fun parts of camping is getting to and setting your site up. She wanted to be there. But, like most cyclists, she also wanted to simply put her head down and move through less than ideal conditions to our destination.
.
.
She never once complained, and after getting to camp, was nothing but a walking smile, briefly checking out the tunnel we we would explore the next morning, raiding the larder on my bike (even though she carried all her food on hers), and watching the mist and rain roll over the hills roughly undulating away from the Caprock Escarpment."
.
.

instagram post: â€œSIMAMA!â€ was one of the first words I was taught in Swahili to help me get by. It means to stop, or stand still. I had been hanging off the back of a rickety old motorcycle, aka pikipiki (which is way more fun to say, by the way), with one hand dangling with my camera shooting wildly and the other gripping the metal bar I was straddling, trying to balance and absorb the bumps from the muddy terrain. I had been shooting my friend @nicholekbaker, a pathologist assistant PA and mountain biker, as she ventured into the backcountry of Uganda by bicycle. Nichole was working to improve third world medicine and had big dreams to make it happen. Coming from a place of healing and recovery, focusing her time and energy on helping others was just what she needed to move forward. | Click the link in our bio to learn about Nicholeâ€™s work with Path of Logic and how they have supplied communities with solar lights from @mpowerdinc, allowing students to study past sunset and into the dark of night, increasing their odds at successfully passing examinations. | ğŸ“·by: @kylie.fly | Featured pack from the Siskin/Salida Series #ospreypacks

instagram post:
The schools Nichole visits focus on elementary aged students, which includes students who are testing into secondary school. It is often the case that many students do not have electricity or power in the home and cannot study past dark. Providing solar lights to these students allows them to study past sunset and into the dark of night, increasing their odds at successfully passing examinations. Many of her stops are impromptu, encouraged by smiling faces and running children who are curious about her bicycle.
.
.
@nicholekbakerâ€™s work in Uganda is a good reminder to â€œsimama,â€ or stand still in our gratitude for the resources, health and freedom we have to explore our passions and pursue meaningful work within our own communities and across the globe. Every new travel experience is enriched by a deeper recognition, understanding and appreciation of the wonderful planet we live on and the people we get to share it with. | ğŸ“· by:@kylie.fly | Featured pack from the Siskin/Salida Series #ospreypacks

instagram post:
Dear Osprey friends and family,

In recent days weâ€™ve been contacted by a number of you, faithful customers, sharing your stories of adventures delayed or rerouted close to home, even backyards. You sent photos of packed Osprey bags waiting patiently by the front door. You have shown determination, passion and grit, you have inspired us with your fortitude. You have also reminded us how important empathy is in times of crisis because all of you are telling us that you are not giving up. And neither would we. This bit of defiance, this statement of hope will serve as a guiding light for us here at Osprey. Your determination inspires us to take one step forward and then another. This trail is one we hike together.

During this time, osprey.com is open and all orders will ship free. To help support our retail partners, our dealer service team is taking orders and our dealer locator provides an up-to-date view of local store hours, inventory, curbside pick-up and same-day delivery options. Our distribution center is shipping everything.

For our Osprey team and the communities in which we operate, we have pivoted our priorities to prevent the spread of COVID-19. We have implemented a temporary telecommuting policy in our U.S. and European offices. If a role must be performed on-site, we are actively practicing social distancing, increased sanitization, and ensuring safe work environments and practices.

While our love of adventure has not dwindled in this trying time, we are finding moments to celebrate the outdoors responsibly. We believe adventure is open to anyone and found everywhereâ€”even, and especially, in your own backyard.

As the situation evolves, we are doing our best to stay current and support the communities, partners and relationships we have fostered through our 46 years of business.

Please keep sending us your stories. How are you changing it up without giving it up? Weâ€™ll share the best ones with our audience to inspire. Whether youâ€™re summiting lofty peaks in remote basement pillow forts or venturing out for everyday essentialsâ€”keep sharing because like you to us, we promise to remain faithfully at your side and together we shall prevail.
prompt: Write a heartfelt message to Osprey friends and family, sharing stories of resilience and hope during the COVID-19 pandemic.

instagram post: This summer, a friend and I decided to go for an impromptu overnight camping trip on the summit of a nearby mountain called Mt. English. After bushwhacking for a few hours from the end of a logging road, we came to some beautiful alpine meadows with the wildflowers in full bloom. From here, we made our way up some scree, scrambled to the summit, and got cozy in our sleeping bags for the night. I stayed up and watched the milky way rise about the surrounding mountains on a moonless night-- it was so serene. I woke to frost on my sleeping bag and the sky slowly changing into hues of orange and red. This photo was taken just before leaving the summit, overlooking the glacier below. After that, it was back to the car because my friend had to rush so he wouldn't be late for work that day. All in all, it was a successful mini-adventure. - Vince Schnabl, Osprey Ambassador#ospreypacks | ğŸ“·@vincentschnabl | Featured pack from the Rook/Renn Series #ospreypacks #ospreyambassador

instagram post:
Four of my girlfriends and I spent four days backpacking on the Via Dinarica from outside of Sarajevo to Sutjeska National Park in Bosnia. We saw zero other hikers on the trail the entire way. ZERO! In a land that could be compared in many ways to Yosemite, it was hard to believe that we had it all to ourselves, especially with the fall colors, perfect hiking temps, and sunshine.

During our trip, we met many warm locals who were eager to help us, talk to us (even without sharing a common tongue), and of course share their rakija and food with us. Aside from plenty of bonding time for our friendships to grow even stronger, we rested a LOT, laughed a LOT, slowed life down, put away our phones, and enjoyed getting far (VERY far) off the beaten path, together.

I needed that time desperately, and I'm so grateful to have had the opportunity to finally experience a section of the Via Dinarica with my badass female dream team. | ğŸ“·@travelingjackie | Featured pack from the Farpoint/Fairview, Levity/Lumina Series #ospreypacks #ospreyambassador

More specifically members of the communities through which the Great Divide Mountain Bike Route, the Tour Divide and the Continental Divide Trail pass through. Music for Free is about the wildness and spirit of these people who live with this land by choice and make their lives how they want them to be. Music for free is a gift back and thank you to those that have given so much to those out seeking adventure. Music for Free is meant to honor the truth that under the soil our roots are all bound together. Even though water that falls on the divide ends up in opposing oceans it will all one day come back to touch the dirt as rain. Music for Free is to remind us that we are all connected and that strength and resilience of any system rests in its diversity. | ğŸ“·: @benweavermusic + @keendes | Featured pack from the Raptor/Raven Series #ospreypacks #musicforfree

instagram post: Music for Free is about wildness. How does wildness differ from wilderness? How do we relate to wildness both inner and outer? How does our relationship to wildness connect to our ability to protect public land? Is wildness an inherent quality in all living things that connects each of us to each other, as well as all the other-than-human members of the ecosystems we share this planet with? Music for Free is about discovering and celebrating where our wildness overlap. It is about the rivers. The Grizzly. The Porcupine. The Columbine. The remaining glaciers, and listening to the wisdom they have to impart on us as we move through their homes. Music for Free is about honoring and strengthening relationships, it is about getting as close to the dark as an owl. Music for Free is about moving at the pace of the land. | ğŸ“·: @benweavermusic +@keendes | Featured pack from the Raptor/Raven Series |#ospreypacks #musicforfree

instagram post: Change does not come from the middle. It comes from the edges. The bike leaves me spending an incredible amount of my time on the edge. Metaphorically, and literally speaking. Music for Free is about living in that space at the edge and bringing some of its truth and magic a little closer to the middle. We discovered incredible people, with incredible truths, living among the remaining wild spaces of this landscape. In hindsight it should be no surprise. The miraculousness of your discoveries coincide with the miraculousness of the places you seek them out. Daylite Artist Series featuring @prettybirdpaper: What are some challenges of having your passion also be your profession? ğŸ”¹ğŸ”¹
Itâ€™s like working in your bed. Itâ€™s so comfortable, and as far as work goes, itâ€™s pretty amazing. But then when itâ€™s time to go to sleep and youâ€™re in the same place where you worked all day, you donâ€™t sleep as well. Everyone tells you not to do it, because that association is real. So basically, painting doesnâ€™t always get to be as peaceful for me as it once consistently was. I went to a huge stationary tradeshow in May and was so burnt out at the end that I told everyone I was never going to paint another card. (Untrue.) instagram post:
We asked @sarahvirginiauhl the eternal question for any artist: how do you know when a piece is done?
ğŸ”¸ğŸ”¸ğŸ”¸ I think this is a place where the business mind needs to meet the artistic mind. My success is based upon a balance of both. If I were to allow myself to stay in my artistic brain, reworking pieces of art until near perfection, I would never get anything done. At a certain point, I bring myself back around to the main thing (for me) which is to tell a story that helps connect someone with the wild places or with themselves. I want my work to provide a sense of connection so that if it gets to the point where I feel like my art can offer that to someone else, I donâ€™t need to stay in it for my own sake. That striving for artistic completion is the carrot that keeps me interested in my own work, in starting a new painting or designing a new project that slowly chips away at that desire for making something truly great. The achievement of this sensation is more of a myth than a daily experience, but I like it that way nonetheless. | Click the link in our bio to win this custom pack! | #ospreypacks #giveaway #art
prompt: Write a post featuring @sarahvirginiauhl's insights on balancing artistic vision with business acumen.

instagram post:
Tune in tonight at 6:30 PM MST to watch @drawingfromnature do a LIVE sketch from her studio in Denver! | What recent project or piece are you most proud of and why?
ğŸ”¸ 
This past summer I was invited by @somethingindependent to be the lead artist for an event they host during the winter & summer @outdoorretailer shows called TRADE SCHOOL (four-days of inspired discussion, original art and informal collision with leading athletes, advocates, entrepreneurs and artists of the outdoor industry). From the start to still now, I feel very honored to have been a part of such an awesome experience and team.
ğŸ”¸
ğŸ”¸
 The first step was showing up and starting the conversations. I wanted to incorporate the summer event themes of Women, Water & the West, while taking advantage of the creative power of the group. Then after a little research frenzy and sketchbook inspiration, I pitched the idea to two of my good friends and inspiring artists @pharen_art and @katcarney. They miraculously bought my crazy and we started the process of working to create a collaborative mixed-media collage of our mediums that we wanted to represent the themes through. When all finished, the artworks blew all of our imaginations. | #ospreypacks #art #slowtv #giveaway
prompt: Create an engaging post highlighting @drawingfromnature's upcoming LIVE sketch and share her story about her most proud project, TRADE SCHOOL.

instagram post: Daylite Artist Series featuring @sarahvirginiauhl ğŸ”¹ğŸ”¹How does your work comment on current social or political issues? ğŸ”¹ğŸ”¹ My artwork carries my personal focus on loving our Earth and being kind to one another.  I am motivated by the organizations I partner with because they tend to be leaders in moving the needle for conservation, climate change, or water issues.  My hope is that the artwork I create can be used as a tool, to bring more people into the conversation around these topics and to feel their own personal connection to these issues.  I am more comfortable making a political statement as an artist by partnering with the experts; groups like The Access Fund, Conservation Colorado, American Rivers, and The Wilderness Society.  If a whimsical painting of an endangered wild and scenic river helps someone learn about how they can help protect rivers, I feel like I have done my job.  If sharing a photo of my adventures into the wild to paint helps someone make more time for themselves to get outside, I feel as though I have done my job.  I believe that every droplet of inspiration shared has an immeasurable ripple effect into peoples lives that then leads them towards actions of their own.  The more inspiration I put out, the more impact I feel I can make around social and political issues. | #ospreypacks #giveaway #publiclands
prompt: Write a post for Daylite Artist Series featuring @sarahvirginiauhl, highlighting her artwork's impact on social and political issues.

In May of 2022 #OspreyAthlete, Jessica Baker (@skidiva) and Rachael Burks (@rachaelburks) boarded a renewable energy sailboat on an arctic ski expedition to venture along Greenland's west coast fjords and towering mountains.

With the intention to observe and document the environmental changes that have occurred over the years and attempt some of Greenland's most aesthetic ski lines along the way, "Going Greenland" is a documentary film about our connection to wild spaces and the juxtaposition of having an impact on our environment.

instagram post:
Inspired by his previous "Crossing" in Iceland last fall, #OspreyAthlete Payson McElveen @paysonmcelveen has knocked another traverse off his list. With the help of Tasmanian endurance rider @oneflukeshot, Payson pieced together a 360 mile route across Tasmania that crescendoed in difficulty, beginning on the wild, largely uninhabited northwestern coast and concluded on the white sand beaches of the Bay of Fires after 32 hours and over 34,000 feet of climbing. 

The island brought him face-to-face with three Tiger Snakes, one of the most venomous on the planet, hundreds of wallabies and wombats, and the friendly locals of Tasmania's rural communities.

The forthcoming film, produced in conjunction with Joey Schusler and Thomas Woodson and edited by Aidan Haley, will premier at the 2023 Sea Otter Classic and aims to share stories far beyond the athletic achievement of this ride.

Did you know that weâ€™re proud members of @conservationalliance who recently announced the Dolores River in Colorado as one of their four Advocacy Priority Campaigns for 2022? Beginning high in the San Juan Mountains of southwestern Colorado, it flows 230 miles until it joins the Colorado River in Utahâ€™s red rock desert near Moab. McPhee Dam and Reservoir were built in the 1980â€™s to support the growing agricultural communities in the region, and to provide much-needed water for the Ute Mountain Ute Tribe in Towaoc. 

This year, they will be joining groups advocating for protection of the lower Dolores River through:

ğŸ’¦  A bill to designate a 75,000-acre National Conservation Area spanning from the base of McPhee Reservoir to the San Miguel/Montrose County line, which includes more than 70 miles of the Dolores River, establishes the Ponderosa Gorge Roadless Area, and protects special river values.

Theyâ€™re partnering with Dolores River Boating Advocates in the effort to protect this beautiful river and surrounding lands.

"What advice would you give to someone whoâ€™s JUST getting started hiking, to encourage and support them?

I began my hiking career on the trails at Oconee Forest Park, a small wooded area behind the intramural sports fields at the University of Georgia. I didnâ€™t really know what hiking was back then, and I didnâ€™t own 'hiking clothes' or trail maps. It was basically impossible to get lost there, due to the small nature of it and the fact that every trail led back to a parking lot. I spent countless hours winding through the woods with my dogs, the trees a refuge from having my nose in textbooks and sitting under fluorescent lights in classrooms. There were no grand views, waterfalls, or picturesque destinations. Just woods, a stream, bugs and wildlife, and dirt beneath my feet.

My biggest piece of advice for someone whoâ€™s just starting is to just GO. The destination doesnâ€™t have to be awe-inspiring. The hike doesnâ€™t have to be epic. If you donâ€™t know how to read a map, go where you donâ€™t need one. You donâ€™t have to have the best gear or even the right shoes. Find a safe wooded area near your home, wear whatever you already own, lace up whatever shoes youâ€™ve got, and take a walk. Spend time with dirt under your feet and wind on your skin. Taste and smell the aroma of the trees and plants around you. Get used to the way your body moves on uneven terrain. Find your stride. Learn your pace and your stamina. Start where youâ€™re at." - @adventurelikeagirl | ğŸ“· by @emtrod90 | Featured pack from the Manta/Mira Series

instagram post:
In 2019, #OspreyAmbassador @kyehalpin along with @freddy.most set out to find a creative route through the Tetons. The popular Teton Crest Trail covers the southern portion of the range but the northern section is a vast, often unexplored expanse with vague, undeveloped trails and difficult terrain. Their vision was to find a route traveling the entire length of the Tetons along the hydrological divide - the line where the water flows from either the west or the east. 

Following this line through the Tetons proved to be more of a challenge than either of them had expected and pushed them to the edge of their physical and psychological boundaries. Watch Teton Center Punch in full via the link in our bio. 

ğŸ¥ @noahwaldron.mov #ospreypacks

instagram post:

#OspreyAthlete and professional explorer @RayZahab feels very fortunate to do what he loves. He has run over 17,000 km across the far corners of the world in the last 15 years. But the greatest gift in his life has been being a dad. Every week, they hold "family day," a day of no pressure adventure and quality time with his wife, Kath, and their two girls, Mia and Anika. 

''On all of my expeditions since then, I dream about days when I return home, to create our own family adventures big and small. I see in my daughters a growing fascination of what adventures are out there waiting for them, and it stokes me so much that they are getting increasingly excited to explore in bigger way, and they have a big goal set for the near future!'' - Ray
